question: Question 1 Let [latex]v_{1}=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 2 \\ 0\end{array}\right][/latex] and [latex]v_{2}=\left[\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 1 \\ 3\end{array}\right][/latex] be two vectors. The value of the coefficient [latex]\alpha[/latex] in the expression [latex]v_{1}=\alpha v_{2}+e[/latex], which minimizes the length of the error vector [latex]e[/latex], is
Question 2 The rate of increase, of a scalar field [latex]f(x, y, z)=x y z[/latex] in the direction [latex]v=(2,1,2)[/latex] at a point [latex](0,2,1)[/latex] is
Question 3 Let [latex]w^{4}=16 j[/latex]. Which of the following cannot be a value of [latex]w[/latex] ?
solution:
[latex]w=(2) j^{1 / 4}[/latex] [latex]w=2(0+j)^{1 / 4}[/latex] [latex]w=2\left[e^{j(2 n+1) \pi / 2}\right]^{1 / 4}[/latex]
[latex]=2\left[e^{j(2 n+1) \pi / 8}\right][/latex] For [latex]n=0[/latex],  
[latex]w=e^{j \pi / 8}[/latex] For [latex]n=2[/latex],  
[latex]w=2 e^{5 \pi j / 8}[/latex] For [latex]n=4[/latex],  
[latex]w=2 e^{9 \pi j / 8}[/latex]

question: Question 4 The value of the contour integral, [latex]\oint_{c}\left(\frac{z+2}{z^{2}+2 z+2}\right) d z[/latex], where the contour [latex]C[/latex] is [latex]\left\{z:\left|z+1-\frac{3}{2} j\right|=1\right\}[/latex], taken in the counter clockwise direction, is
solution:
[latex]
I=\oint_{c} \frac{z+2}{z^{2}+2 z+2} d z ; \quad c=\left|z+1-\frac{3}{2} i\right|=1
[/latex] Poles are given [latex](z+1)^{2}+1=0[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& z+1= \pm \sqrt{-1} \\
& z=-1+j,-1-j 
\end{aligned}
[/latex] where [latex]-1-i[/latex] lies outside ' [latex]c[/latex] ' [latex]z=(-1,1) \text { lies inside }  'c'[/latex]. by [latex]\mathrm{CRT}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\oint_{c} f(z) d z & =2 \pi i \operatorname{Res}(f(z), z=-1+j) \\
& =2 \pi i\left(\frac{z+2}{2(z+1)}\right)_{z=-1+i}\\
& =2 \pi i\left(\frac{-1+j+2}{2(-1+j+1)}\right) \\
& =\pi(1+j)
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 5 Let the sets of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix [latex]B[/latex] be [latex]\left\{\lambda_{k} \mid 1 \leq k \leq n\right\}[/latex] and [latex]\left\{v_{k} \mid 1 \leq k \leq n\right\}[/latex], respectively. For any invertible matrix [latex]P[/latex], the sets of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix [latex]A[/latex], where [latex]B=P^{-1} A B[/latex], respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} & B & =P^{-1} A P \\ A & =P B P^{-1}\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow A, B[/latex] are called matrices similar. [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Both [latex]A, B[/latex] have same set 7 eigen values But eigen vectors of [latex]A, B[/latex] are different. Let [latex]B X=\lambda X[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad\left(P^{-1} A P\right) X=\lambda X[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \quad A(P X)=\lambda(P X)[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Eigen vectors of [latex]A[/latex] are [latex]P X[/latex].

options.A: [latex]\left\{\lambda_{k} \operatorname{det}\mid 1 \leq k \leq n\right\}[/latex] and [latex]\left\{P v_{k} \mid 1 \leq k \leq n\right\}[/latex]
options.C: [latex]\left\{\lambda_{k} \mid 1 \leq k \leq n\right\}[/latex] and [latex]\left\{P v_{k} \mid 1 \leq k \leq n\right\}[/latex]
options.D: [latex]\left\{\lambda_{k} \mid 1 \leq k \leq n\right\}[/latex] and [latex]\left\{P^{-1} v_{k} \mid 1 \leq k \leq n\right\}[/latex]

question: Question 6 In a semiconductor, if the Fermi energy level lies in the conduction band, then the semiconductor is known as
solution: As the Fermi lies inside the conduction band hence it is degenerate [latex]n[/latex]-type semiconductor.

question: Question 7 For an intrinsic semiconductor at temperature [latex]T=0 \mathrm{~K}[/latex], which of the following statement is true?
solution: Intrinsic semiconductor at [latex]\mathrm{T}=0 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] behaves as an insulator. Hence, valence band is completely filled with electron and conduction band is completely empty.

options.A: All energy states in the valence band are filled with electrons and all energy states in the conduction band are empty of electrons.
options.B: All energy states in the valence band are empty of electrons and all energy states in the conduction band are filled with electrons.
options.C: All energy states in the valence and conduction band are filled with holes.
options.D: All energy states in the valence and conduction band are filled with electrons.

question: Question 8 A series [latex]R L C[/latex] circuit has a quality factor [latex]Q[/latex] of 1000 at a center frequency of [latex]10^{6} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. The possible values of [latex]R, L[/latex] and [latex]C[/latex] are

Question 9 For a MOS capacitor, [latex]V_{f b}[/latex] and [latex]V_{t}[/latex] are the flat-band voltage and the threshold voltage, respectively. The variation of the depletion width [latex]\left(W_{\text {dep }}\right)[/latex] for varying gate voltage [latex]\left(V_{g}\right)[/latex] is best represented by
solution: [latex]\because[/latex] We know [latex]V_{G} \lt V_{F B}[/latex] then accumulation mode. [latex]\therefore[/latex] In accumulation mode [latex]W_{d}=0[/latex] because there is no depletion charge. Now, [latex]V_{F B} \lt V_{G} \lt V_{T} \Rightarrow[/latex] then depletion and inversion mode. [latex]\therefore[/latex] Depletion width is available. [latex]\therefore V_{G} \gt V_{T} \Rightarrow[/latex] Strong inversion. [latex]\therefore[/latex] Depletion width [latex]W_{d} \Rightarrow[/latex] Constant. And [latex]W_{d}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \epsilon\left|\phi_{S}\right|}{q N_{S}}}[/latex] and [latex]\left|\phi_{S}\right| \propto V_{G}[/latex] But after strong inversion, [latex]W_{d}[/latex] remains constant. [latex]\therefore[/latex] Correction option is (B).

question: Question 10 Consider a narrow band signal, propagating in a lossless dielectric medium [latex]\left(\epsilon_{r}=4, \mu_{r}=1\right)[/latex], with phase velocity [latex]v_{p}[/latex] and group velocity [latex]v_{g}[/latex]. Which of the following statement is true? ( [latex]c[/latex] is the velocity of light in vacuum.)
solution: Phase velocity, [latex]V_{p}=\frac{\omega}{\beta}=\frac{\omega}{\omega \sqrt{\mu \epsilon}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{0} \epsilon_{0}}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_{r} \epsilon_{r}}}=\frac{C}{\sqrt{\mu_{r} \epsilon_{r}}}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad V_{p} \lt C[/latex] Group velocity, [latex]V_{g}=\frac{d \omega}{d \beta}=\frac{V_{p}}{1-\frac{\omega}{V_{p}} \frac{d V_{p}}{d \omega}}[/latex] Here, [latex]\quad V_{p} \neq f(\omega)[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad V_{g}=V_{p} \lt C[/latex] Hence, [latex]\quad V_{p} \lt C[/latex] [latex]\quad \quad V_{g} \lt C[/latex]

question: Question 11 In the circuit shown below, [latex]V_{1}[/latex] and [latex]V_{2}[/latex] are bias voltages. Based on input and output impedances, the circuit behaves as a
solution: Here from circuit, [latex]M_{1}[/latex] is common-gate amplifier and [latex]M_{2}[/latex] behaves as an active load. By using properties of common gate (CG) amplifier, Input impedance [latex]\left(R_{i}\right)[/latex] is low Output impedance [latex]\left(R_{0}\right)[/latex] is high So, it is a current amplifier. Current amplifier is a current controlled current source.

question: Question 12 A cascade of common-source amplifiers in a unity gain feedback configuration oscillates when
solution: For oscillation, Loop gain magnitude [latex]\geq 1[/latex]. Phase of loop gain [latex]=360^{\circ}[/latex] So, correct answer is option (D). In options, closes loop gain is mentioned technically it should be loop gain.

options.A: the closed loop gain is less than 1 and the phase shift is less than [latex]180^{\circ}[/latex].
options.B: the closed loop gain is greater than 1 and the phase shift is less than [latex]180^{\circ}[/latex].
options.C: the closed loop gain is less than 1 and the phase shift is greater than [latex]180^{\circ}[/latex].
options.D: the closed loop gain is greater than 1 and the phase shift is greater than [latex]180^{\circ}[/latex].

question: Question 13 In the circuit shown below, [latex]P[/latex] and [latex]Q[/latex] are the inputs. The logical function realized by the circuit shown below is
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
\text { Output } & =\bar{Q} \cdot I_{0}+Q \cdot I_{1} \\
& =\bar{Q} \cdot 0+Q \cdot P \\
& =P Q
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 14 The synchronous sequential circuit shown below works at a clock frequency of [latex]1 \mathrm{GHz}[/latex]. The throughput, in [latex]\mathrm{M}[/latex] bits/s, and the latency, in ns, respectively, are

Question 15 The open loop transfer function of a unity negative feedback system is [latex]G(s)=\frac{k}{s\left(1+s T_{1}\right)\left(1+s T_{2}\right)}[/latex], where [latex]k, T_{1}[/latex] and [latex]T_{2}[/latex] are positive constants. The phase crossover frequency, in rad/s, is
solution:
We know phase crossover frequency is that frequency at which phase of the open loop transfer function is [latex]-180^{\circ}[/latex]. [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad G(s) & =\frac{K}{s\left(1+s T_{1}\right)\left(1+s T_{2}\right)} \\
G(j \omega) & =\frac{K}{(j \omega)\left(1+j \omega T_{1}\right)\left(1+j \omega T_{2}\right)} \\
\text{Phase of }G(j \omega) & =\phi =-90-\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega T_{1}\right) - \tan ^{-1}\left(\omega T_{2}\right) \\
\therefore \quad \text { At } \omega &=\omega_{p c}, \phi =-180  \\
-180 & =-90-\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega_{p c} T_{1}\right)-\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega_{p c} T_{2}\right) \\
9 \quad 90 & =\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega_{p c} T_{1}\right)+\tan ^{-1}\left(\omega_{p c} T_{2}\right) \\
\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{\omega_{p c} T_{1}+\omega_{p c} T_{2}}{1-\omega_{p c}^{2} T_{1} T_{2}}\right) & =90 \\
1-\omega_{p c}^{2} T_{1} T_{2} & =0 \\
\omega_{p c} & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{T_{1} T_{2}}}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 16 Consider a system with input [latex]x(t)[/latex] and output [latex]y(t)=x\left(e^{t}\right)[/latex]. The system is
solution:
We have, [latex]\quad y(t)=x\left(e^{t}\right)[/latex] At [latex]t=0[/latex] [latex]y(0)=x(1)[/latex] i.e. present value of output depends on future value of input, hence it is non-causal. For Time Variant:
Delay the input, [latex]
y(t)=x\left(e^{t}-t_{0}\right) \quad . . . (i)
[/latex] Delay the output, [latex]
y\left(t-t_{0}\right)=x\left(e^{t-t_{0}}\right) \quad . . . (ii)
[/latex] i.e. equations (i) [latex]\neq[/latex] (ii) Hence, it is time variant system.

question: Question 17 Let [latex]m(t)[/latex] be a strictly band-limited signal with bandwidth [latex]B[/latex] and energy [latex]E[/latex]. Assuming [latex]\omega_{0}=10 B[/latex], the energy in the signal [latex]m(t) \cos \omega_{0} t[/latex] is
Question 18 The Fourier transform [latex]X(\omega)[/latex] of [latex]x(t)=e^{-t^{2}}[/latex] is
solution: We know; [latex]\quad e^{-a t^{2}} ; a>0 \stackrel{F T}{\rightleftharpoons} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} \cdot e^{-\omega^{2} / 4 a}[/latex] Here; [latex]a=1[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad X(\omega)=\sqrt{\pi} \cdot e^{-\omega^{2} / 4}[/latex]

Question 20 For a real signal, which of the following is/are valid power spectral density/densities?
solution: (i) [latex]S_{x}(\omega) \geq 0[/latex] (ii) [latex]S_{x}(\omega)[/latex] is even function Hence, options (A) and (B) are valid power spectral densities.

question: Question 21 The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of an ADC with a full-scale sinusoidal input is given to be [latex]61.96 \mathrm{~dB}[/latex]. The resolution of the ADC is _____ bits. (rounded off to the nearest integer).
Question 22 In the circuit shown below, the current [latex]i[/latex] flowing through [latex]200 \Omega[/latex] resistor is ____ [latex]m A[/latex] (rounded off to two decimal places).

Question 23 For the two port network shown below, the [latex][Y][/latex]-parameters is given as [latex]
[Y]=\frac{1}{100}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
2 & -1 \\
-1 & 4 / 3
\end{array}\right] S
[/latex] The value of load impedance [latex]Z_{L}[/latex], in [latex]\Omega[/latex], for maximum power transfer will be ____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]
[Y]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{2}{100} & -\frac{1}{100} \\
-\frac{1}{100} & \frac{4}{300}
\end{array}\right]
[/latex] For the given [latex]Y[/latex]-parameter the two-port network is [latex]
Y_{11}=Y_{a}+Y_{b}=\frac{2}{100}
[/latex][ [latex]Y_{12}=Y_{21}=-Y_{b}=-\frac{1}{100}[/latex] [latex]Y_{22}=Y_{b}+Y_{c}=\frac{4}{300}[/latex] On solving, [latex]\quad Y_{b}=\frac{1}{100} S[/latex] [latex]
Y_{a}=\frac{1}{100} S
[/latex] [latex]

Y_{c}=\frac{1}{300} S
[/latex] The network becomes, Converting [latex]\Delta[/latex] - to [latex]\lambda [/latex] [latex]
Z_{Th}=60+[(20+10)||60]=60+\frac{30 \times 60}{30+60}=80 \Omega
[/latex] For maximum power transfer, [latex]
Z_{L}=Z_{\text {Th }}=80 \Omega
[/latex]

question: Question 24 For the circuit shown below, the propagation delay of each NAND gate is [latex]1 \mathrm{~ns}[/latex]. The critical path delay, in ns, is ____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution: The given circuit can be drawn as; [latex]\therefore \quad[/latex] The critical path delay [latex]=1 \mathrm{~ns}+1 \mathrm{~ns}=2 \mathrm{~ns}[/latex]

question: Question 25 In the circuit shown below, switch [latex]S[/latex] was closed for a long time. If the switch is opened at [latex]t=0[/latex], the maximum magnitude of the voltage [latex]V_{R}[/latex], in volts, is ____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).

Question 26 A random variable [latex]X[/latex], distributed normally as [latex]N(0,1)[/latex], undergoes the transformation [latex]Y=h(X)[/latex], given in the figure. The form of the probability density function of [latex]Y[/latex] is (In the options given below, [latex]a, b, c[/latex] are non-zero constants and [latex]g(y)[/latex] is piece-wise continuous function)
solution:
[latex]X=N(0,1)[/latex] [latex]f_X(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{-x^2/2}[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
Y= & -1 ; x \leq-2 \\
& 0 ;-1 \leq x \leq 1 \\
& 1 ; x \geq 2 \\
& x+1 ;-2 \leq x \leq-1 \\
& x-1 ; 1 \leq x \leq 2
\end{aligned}
[/latex] [latex]Y[/latex] is taking discrete set of values and a continuous range of values, so it is mixed random variable. From the given options, density function of '[latex]Y[/latex]' will be. [latex]
f_{Y}(y)=a \delta(y+1)+b \delta(y)+c \delta(y-1)+g(y)
[/latex]

question: Question 27 The value of the line integral [latex]\int_{P}^{Q}\left(z^{2} d x+3 y^{2} d y+2 x z d z\right)[/latex] along the straight line joining the points [latex]P(1,1,2)[/latex] and [latex]Q(2,3,1)[/latex] is
solution:
[latex]\int_{P}^{Q} z^{2} d x+3 y^{2} d y+2 x z d z[/latex] along the line joining the points [latex]P(1,1,2)[/latex] and [latex]Q(2,3,1)[/latex] is [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{P(1,2)}^{P(2,1)} z^{2} d x+2 x y d z+\int_{y=1}^{3} 3 y^{2} d y \\
& =\left(x z^{2}\right)_{(1,2)}^{(2,1)}+\left(y^{3}\right)_{1}^{3} \\
& =\left(2 \times 1^{2}-1 \times 2^{2}\right)+\left(3^{3}-1^{3}\right) \\
& =-2+26=24
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 37 Consider a discrete-time periodic signal with period [latex]N=5[/latex]. Let the discrete-time Fourier series (DTFS) representation be [latex]x[n]=\sum_{k=0}^{4} a_{k} e^{\frac{j k 2 \pi n}{5}}[/latex], where [latex]a_{0}=1, a_{1}=3 j, a_{2}=2 j[/latex], [latex]a_{3}=-2 j[/latex] and [latex]a_{4}=-3 j[/latex]. The value of the sum [latex]\sum_{n=0}^{4} x[n] \sin \frac{4 \pi n}{5}[/latex] is

Question 38 Let an input [latex]x[n][/latex] having discrete time Fourier transform. [latex]X\left(e^{j \Omega}\right)=1-e^{-j \Omega}+2 e^{-3 j \Omega}[/latex] be passed through an LTI system. The frequency response of the LTI system is [latex]H\left(e^{j \Omega}\right)=1-\frac{1}{2} e^{-j 2 \Omega}[/latex]. The output [latex]y[n][/latex] of the system is

Question 39 Let [latex]x(t)=10 \cos (10.5 \mathrm{Wt})[/latex] be passed through an LTI system having impulse response [latex]h(t)=\pi\left(\frac{\sin W t}{\pi t}\right)^{2} \cos 10 W t[/latex]. The output of the system is
solution:
Given [latex]h(t)[/latex] is Real and Even. When sinusoidal input applied to LTI system having even impulse response, then output will also be sinusoidal. here, 
[latex]
y(t)=\left.H(W)\right|_{W=10.5 W} \cdot 10 \cos (10.5 W t)
[/latex] let,  
[latex]
h(t)=f(t) \cos 10 W t
[/latex] where, [latex]

f(t)=\pi\left(\frac{\sin W t}{\pi t}\right)^{2}
[/latex] Now;

[latex]
H(W)=\frac{1}{2}[F(W+10 W)+F(W-10 W)]
[/latex] [latex]\left.\therefore \quad H(W)\right|_{W=10.5 W}=\frac{3}{8} W[/latex] Hence,

[latex]
\begin{aligned}
y(t) & =\left(\frac{3}{8} W\right)(10 \cos 10.5 W t) \\
& =\frac{15}{4} W \cos 10.5 W t
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 40 Let [latex]x_{1}(t)[/latex] and [latex]x_{2}(t)[/latex] be two band-limited signals having bandwidth [latex]B=4 \pi \times 10^{3} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \mathrm{each}[/latex]. In the figure below, the Nyquist sampling frequency, in rad/s, required to sample [latex]y(t)[/latex], is
solution: Given that, [latex]x_{1}(t)[/latex] and [latex]x_{2}(t)[/latex] are two bandlimited signals having bandwidth [latex]B=4 \pi \times 10^{3} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}[/latex]. and [latex]y(t)=x_{2}(t) \cos \left(12 \pi \times 10^{3} t\right)+x_{1}(t) \cos \left(4 \pi \times 10^{3} t\right)[/latex] So, [latex]\text{Nyquist Rate }=2\omega _{max}=2[16 \pi \times 10^3]=32 \pi \times 10^3\; rad/sec[/latex]

options.A: [latex]\left[\begin{array}{cc}S_{11} e^{-j 2 \theta_{1}} & S_{12} e^{-j\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right)} \\ S_{21} e^{-j\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right)} & S_{22} e^{-j 2 \theta_{2}}\end{array}\right][/latex]
options.B: [latex]\left[\begin{array}{cc}S_{11} e^{j 2 \theta_{1}} & S_{12} e^{-j\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right)} \\ S_{21} e^{-j\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right)} & S_{22} e^{j 2 \theta_{2}}\end{array}\right][/latex]
options.C: [latex]\left[\begin{array}{cc}S_{1} e^{j 2 \theta_{1}} & S_{12} e^{e j\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right)} \\ S_{21} e^{j\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right)} & S_{22} e^{j 2 \theta_{2}}\end{array}\right][/latex]
options.D: [latex]\left[\begin{array}{cc}S_{11} e^{-j 2 \theta_{1}} & S_{12} e^{e j\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right)} \\ S_{21} e^{j\left(\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}\right)} & S_{22} e^{-j 2 \theta_{2}}\end{array}\right][/latex]

Question 43 The electric field of a plane electromagnetic wave is [latex]E=a_{x} C_{1 x} \cos (\omega t-\beta z)+a_{y} C_{1 y} \cos (\omega t-\beta z+\theta) \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m}[/latex] Which of the following combination(s) will give rise to a left handed elliptically polarized (LHEP) wave?
Question 44 The following circuit(s) representing a lumped element equivalent of an infinitesimal section of a transmission line is/are
Question 45 The value of the integral [latex]\iint_{R} x y d x d y[/latex] over the region [latex]R[/latex], given in the figure, is ___ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
I & =\iint_{R} x y d x d y \\
& =\int_{y=0}^{1} \int_{x=-y}^{y} x y d x d y+\int_{y=1}^{2} \int_{x=y-2}^{2-y} x y d x d y \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} y\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)_{-y}^{y} d y+\int_{1}^{2} y\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)_{y-2}^{2-y} d y \\
& =0+0=0
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 46 In an extrinsic semiconductor, the hole concentration is given to be [latex]1.5 n_{i}[/latex] where [latex]n_{i}[/latex] is the intrinsic carrier concentration of [latex]1 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}[/latex]. The ratio of electron to hole mobility for equal hole and electron drift current is given as  ___ (rounded off to two decimal places).

Question 47 The asymptotic magnitude Bode plot of a minimum phase system is shown in the figure.

The transfer function of the system is [latex](s)=\frac{k(s+z)^{a}}{s^{b}(s+p)^{c}}[/latex], where [latex]k, z, p, a, b[/latex] and [latex]c[/latex] are positive constants. The value of [latex](a+b+c)[/latex] is ___ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
From the Bode magnitude plot, it is clear that there is one pole at origin, [latex]\therefore[/latex] [latex]b=1[/latex] and at frequency
[latex]
\omega_{1} [/latex], system has a zero [latex]\therefore[/latex] [latex]a=1[/latex] and at frequency
[latex]
\omega_{2} [/latex], system has a two poles [latex]
\begin{aligned}
 \therefore \quad c&=2 \\
 \therefore \quad a+b+c&=1+1+2 \\
 a+b+c&=4
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 48 Let [latex]x_{1}(t)=u(t+1.5)-u(t-1.5)[/latex] and [latex]x_{2}(t)[/latex] is shown in the figure below. For [latex]y(t)=x_{1}(t) * x_{2}(t)[/latex], the [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} y(t) d t[/latex] is ___. (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]
x_{1}(t)=u(t+1.5)-u(t-1.5)
[/latex] [latex] ]\Rightarrow x_1(t)=rect\left ( \frac{t}{3} \right )[/latex] [latex] ] x_1(t)=rect\left ( \frac{t}{3} \right )  \overset{FT}{\leftrightarrow} 3Sa(1.5\omega )[/latex] Now,

[latex]
x_{2}(t)=\delta(t+3)+\operatorname{rect}\left(\frac{t}{2}\right)+2 \delta(t-2)
[/latex] Taking Fourier transform [latex]
\begin{aligned}
X_{2}(\omega) & =e^{3 j \omega}+2 S a(\omega)+2 e^{-2 j \omega} \\
y(t) & =x_{1}(t) * x_{2}(t) \\
Y(\omega) & =X_{1}(\omega) \cdot X_{2}(\omega) \\
Y(\omega) & =\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} y(t) \cdot e^{-j \omega t} \cdot d t
\end{aligned}
[/latex] We know [latex]\therefore \quad \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} y(t)=Y(0)[/latex] [latex]\therefore \quad Y(0)=X_{1}(0) \cdot X_{2}(0)[/latex]

[latex]=3[1+2+2]=15[/latex]

question: Question 49 Let [latex]X(t)[/latex] be a white Gaussian noise with power spectral density [latex]\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{Hz}[/latex]. If [latex]X(t)[/latex] is input to an LTI system with impulse response [latex]e^{-t} u(t)[/latex]. The average power of the system output is ___ [latex]\mathrm{W}[/latex]. (Rounded off to two decimal place).

Question 50 A transparent dielectric coating is applied to glass [latex]\left(\epsilon_{r}=4, \mu_{r}=1\right)[/latex] to eliminate the reflection of red light [latex]\left(\lambda_{0}=0.75 \mu \mathrm{m}\right)[/latex]. The minimum thickness of the dielectric coating, in [latex]\mu \mathrm{m}[/latex], that can be used is ____ (rounded off to two decimal places).

Question 51 In a semiconductor device, the Fermi-energy level is [latex]0.35 \mathrm{eV}[/latex] above the valence band energy. The effective density of states in the valence band at [latex]T=300 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] is [latex]1 \times 10^{19} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}[/latex]. The thermal equilibrium hole concentration in silicon at [latex]400 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] is ___ [latex]\_\times 10^{13} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}[/latex]. (rounded off to two decimal places). Given [latex]\mathrm{kT}[/latex] at [latex]300 \mathrm{~K}[/latex] is [latex]0.026 \mathrm{eV}[/latex].

Question 52 A sample and hold circuit is implemented using a resistive switch and a capacitor with a time constant of [latex]1 \mu \mathrm{s}[/latex]. The time for sampling switch to stay closed to charge a capacitor adequately to a full scale voltage of [latex]1 \mathrm{~V}[/latex] with 12-bit accuracy is ____ [latex]\mu \mathrm{s}[/latex]. (rounded off to two decimal places)

Question 53 In a given sequential circuit, initial states are [latex]Q_{1}=1[/latex] and [latex]Q_{2}=0[/latex]. For a clock frequency of [latex]1 \mathrm{MHz}[/latex], the frequency of signal [latex]Q_{2}[/latex] in [latex]\mathrm{kHz}[/latex], is ____ (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
Clk & {D}_{\mathbf{1}}=\mathbf{Q}_{\mathbf{2}}[ & D_{\mathbf{2}}=\overline{\mathbf{Q}}_{\mathbf{1}} & {Q}_{\mathbf{1}} & {Q}_{\mathbf{2}} \\
\hline
Initial &  &  & 1 & 0 \\
\hline
1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
2 & 0 & 1 & 0 & 1 \\
3 & 1 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\
4 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex] Therefore, the given counter is having MOD-4 [latex]\therefore[/latex] The frequency of signal [latex]Q_{2}=\frac{f_{i}}{4}=\frac{1000}{4} \mathrm{kHz}=250 \mathrm{kHz}[/latex]

question: Question 54 In the circuit below, the voltage [latex]V_{L}[/latex] is ____ [latex]\_V[/latex]. (rounded off to two decimal places)
solution:
We know, [latex]
 \begin{aligned}
I_{D} & \propto\left(\frac{W}{L}\right) \\
I_{1} & =1 \mathrm{~mA} \\
I_{2} & =\frac{10}{1} \times 1=10 \mathrm{~mA} \\
I_{3} & =10 \mathrm{~mA} \\
I_{4} & =7 \mathrm{~mA} \\
I_{5} & =5 \mathrm{~mA} \\
I_{0} & =I_{4}-I_{5}=7-5=2 \mathrm{~mA} \\
V_{L} & =2 \times 1=2 \mathrm{~V}
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

Question 58 What is the smallest number with distinct digits whose digits add up to 45 ?
solution: The digits should be distinct and smallest number is 123456789.

question: Question 59 In a class of 100 students, (i) there are 30 students who neither like romantic movies nor comedy movies, (ii) the number of students who like romantic movies is twice the number of students who like comedy movies, and (iii) the number of students who like both romantic movies and comedy movies is 20. How many students in the class like romantic movies?
solution:
Let students who like Romantic Movies [latex]=R[/latex]. Students who like Comedy Movies [latex]=C[/latex]. Given [latex]R=2 C[/latex] Also, 30 students do not like Romantic and Comedy Movies both. [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad 100-30&=70=n(R \cap C) \\
\text{and  } n(C \cap R)&=20 \\
n(R \cap C)&=n(R)+n(C)-n(C \cap R)\\
70&=2 C+C-20 
3 C & =90 \\
C & =30 \\
R & =2 C=60
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 60 How many rectangles are present in the given figure?
solution: Number of rectangles [latex]=10[/latex] as square is also called as rectangle.

question: Question 61 Forestland is a planet inhabited by different kinds of creatures. Among other creatures, it is populated by animals all of whom are ferocious. There are also creatures that have claws, and some that do not. All creatures that have claws are ferocious. Based only on the information provided above, which one of the following options can be logically inferred with certainty?
solution: Since, the given function is an even function. Option (D) is only represents the even function.

options.A: All creatures with claws are animals.
options.B: Some creatures with claws are non-ferocious.
options.D: Some ferocious creatures are creatures with claws.

question: Question 62 Which one of the following options represents the given graph?

Question 63 Which one of the following options can be inferred from the given passage alone? When I was a kid, I was partial to stories about other worlds and interplanetary travel. I used to imagine that I could just gaze off into space and be whisked to another planet. [Excerpt from The Truth about Stories by T. King]

options.A: It is a child's description of what he or she likes.
options.B: It is an adult's memory of what he or she liked as a child.
options.C: The child in the passage read stories about interplanetary travel only in parts.
options.D: It teaches us that stories are good for children.

question: Question 64 Out of 1000 individuals in a town, 100 unidentified individuals are covid positive. Due to lack of adequate covid-testing kits, the health authorities of the town devised a strategy to identify these covid-positive individuals. The strategy is to: (i) Collect saliva samples from all 1000 individuals and randomly group them into sets of 5 . (ii) Mix the samples within each set and test the mixed sample for covid. (iii) If the test done in (ii) gives a negative result, then declare all the 5 individuals to be covid negative. (iv) If the test done in (ii) gives a positive result, then all the 5 individuals are separately tested for covid. Given this strategy, no more than ______ testing kits will be required to identify all the 100 covid positive individuals irrespective of how they are grouped.

Question 65 [latex]100 \mathrm{~cm} \times 32 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex] rectangular sheet is folded 5 times. Each time the sheet is folded, the long edge aligns with its opposite side. Eventually, the folded sheet is a rectangle of dimensions [latex]100 \mathrm{~cm} \times 1 \mathrm{~cm}[/latex]. The total number of creases visible when the sheet is unfolded is
solution: [latex]\therefore[/latex] After folding 5 times [latex]=1+2^{1}+2^{2}+2^{3}+2^{4}=1+2+4+8+16=31[/latex]
